title.narrative: West Hemisphere Branch-International Grants

description.narrative: Developing an Interdisciplinary Graduate-level Conservation Program and Conservation.Network in Argentina to improve conservation education and action across Latin America

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Developing an Interdisciplinary Graduate Level Conservation Program and Conservation Network in Argentina to Improve Education and Action

description.narrative: Developing an Interdisciplinary Graduate Level Conservation Program and Conservation Network in Argentina to Improve Education and Action

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Developing an Interdisciplinary Graduate-level Conservation Program and Conservation..Network in Argentina to improve conservation education and action across Latin America

description.narrative: The Recipient will enter into a 2-year cooperative agreement with the Wildlife Without Borders - Latin America and Caribbean (WWB-LAC) program to develop a self-sustaining Graduate Program in Conservation Biology at the University of Buenos Aires, Argentina, and to design and launch a Conservation Network that brings together academics, governmental organizations, non-governmental organizations, conservation practitioners, policy makers, and students. Activities during the first year include conducting an 8-day workshop, 5 days of which will be dedicated to the development of the Conservation Program as follows: 1) designing and refining the Conservation Program's curriculum, 2) identify instructors, 3) addressing implementation strategies and requirements. The remaining 3 days of the workshop will be dedicated to the creation of the Conservation Network including identifying the core implementation team and mentoring body. A follow-up stakeholder meeting will be conducted to review the results of the 8-day workshop, prior to conducting 3 demonstrative field courses of 10 days each for 20-25 students during two consecutive semester to evaluate the program content and delivery. Activities during the second year include an 8-day workshop to evaluate both the program implementation (3 days) and overall project (5 days). A follow-up stakeholder meeting will be conducted to review the results of the evaluations and develop an action plan for next steps.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Apoyo financiero a la maestra en manejo de vida silvestre de la Universidad Nacional de Crdoba, Argentina

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the development and implementation of several new components to the curricula that will enhance and strengthen the interdisciplinary and practical coursework of the Masters in Wildlife Management to be implemented in the 2014-2016 academic cycle. Funding will support the development and implementation of a new course entitled Practice in Biodiversity Conservation and Local Development, scholarships for 10 graduate students, visiting professors, a training workshop for current professors on active teaching and student-centered learning, practical field experiences that enhance coursework, and administrative costs. USFWS substantive involvement will include: 1) participation in the selection and final approval of the recipients of the 10 scholarship students; 2) review and approval of program curriculum prior to implementation; 3) operational involvement during the performance of the award; and 4) redirection of the project because of interrelationships with other projects. A memorandum of understanding will be drafted and approved to outline respective roles and responsibilities under this cooperative agreement.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Conservacin de dos especies focales de aves playeras migs. en Patagonia Sur PP

description.narrative: This project will improve the conservation status of Red Knots and Hudsonian Godwits in southern Patagonia by reducing key threats in two Western Hemisphere Reserve Network sites.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: CONSERVACIN DE DOS ESPECIES

description.narrative: This project will improve the conservation status of Red Knots and Hudsonian Godwits in southern Patagonia by reducing key threats in two Western Hemisphere Reserve Network sites: disturbance of the birds by vehicles and domestic animals, primarily free-running dogs; and mismanagement of household solid waste degrading and devaluing key habitats. This will be accomplished by building an interpretive center; consolidating local support for conservation action; expanding the area and degree of protection of urban natural reserves; and conducting awareness campaigns using innovative methods such as social marketing.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Wildlife Without Borders-Amphibians In Decline

description.narrative: This project will highly improve protection of Somuncura frog by alleviating main threats. Specific objectives include: (1) Highly reducing the number of trout at the headwaters of the stream; (2) Increasing the quality of available habitat for Somuncura frog; (3) Assessing strategies for reducing the impact of climate change; (4) Analyzing the extent and impact of illegal trade.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Working on new house rules: in quest of a better jaguar - farmer coexistence in the Atlantic Forest..of Argentina

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to prevent retaliatory killing of jaguars within the Priority Landscape for Jaguar Protection in the Atlantic Forest. Project activities will develop and implement a surveillance and rapid-response system to address cases of potential or actual jaguar attacks on livestock to avoid and reduce retaliatory killing of jaguars, and establish two pilot livestock farms that adopt production practices that reduce conflicts with jaguars and other large felines and serve as demonstrative units within the Priority Landscape for Jaguar Protection in the Atlantic Forest.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Working on new house rules: in quest of a better jaguar - farmer coexistence in the Atlantic Forest..of Argentina

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to prevent retaliatory killing of jaguars within the Priority Landscape for Jaguar Protection in the Atlantic Forest. Project activities will develop and implement a surveillance and rapid-response system to address cases of potential or actual jaguar attacks on livestock to avoid and reduce retaliatory killing of jaguars, and establish two pilot livestock farms that adopt production practices that reduce conflicts with jaguars and other large felines and serve as demonstrative units within the Priority Landscape for Jaguar Protection in the Atlantic Forest.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Land degradation and species loss in the south of the Gran Chaco Americano: Implementing an..integrated biophysical and social system for its conservation

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to generate integrated conservation actions that link nature reserves with multifunctional landscapes through the participation of local stakeholders. Project objectives include (i) strengthening fire control and management in nature reserves and protected areas through the production of seedlings and reforestation; (ii) reducing threats by managing invasive species, native flora and fauna as well as controlling poaching in multifunctional landscapes and reintroducing native species in protected areas; and (iii) designing and implementing an eco-tourism circuit to connect protected areas and areas of high conservation value. Workshops and field activities will be conducted with teachers, farmers, managers of protected areas, volunteer firefighters, tourist guides, and rural and semi-rural communities.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Land degradation and species loss in the south of the Gran Chaco Americano: Implementing an..integrated biophysical and social system for its conservation

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to generate integrated conservation actions that link nature reserves with multifunctional landscapes through the participation of local stakeholders. Project objectives include (i) strengthening fire control and management in nature reserves and protected areas through the production of seedlings and reforestation; (ii) reducing threats by managing invasive species, native flora and fauna as well as controlling poaching in multifunctional landscapes and reintroducing native species in protected areas; and (iii) designing and implementing an eco-tourism circuit to connect protected areas and areas of high conservation value. Workshops and field activities will be conducted with teachers, farmers, managers of protected areas, volunteer firefighters, tourist guides, and rural and semi-rural communities.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: CONSERVING THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SOMUNCURA FROG (PLEURODEMA SOMUNCURENSIS) IN SOMUNCURA PLATEAU. PATAGONIA, ARGENTINA

description.narrative: Conserving the critically endangered Somuncura frog (Pleurodema somuncurensis) in Somuncura Plateau, in Argentina. In partnership with Universidad Nacional del Centro de la Provincia De Buenos Aires, this project will ensure the long term sustainability of the Somuncura frogs population. Specific objectives include: (1) Impeding access of trout at the headwaters of the stream; (2) Monitoring the extent and effect of chytrid fungus and Ranavirus; (3) Recovering and expanding available habitat; (4) analyzing impacts of illegal trade.

participating-org.narrative: Universidad Nacional del Centro de la Provincia de Buenos Aires

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

receiver-org.narrative: Universidad Nacional del Centro de la Provincia de Buenos Aires

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Conservation of Patagonia's wildlife: implementation of sustainable livestock practices and mitigation of conflicts with native herbivores and carnivores.

description.narrative: The Patagonia region in Argentina once harbored large migratory populations of Guanacos (Lama guanicoe), a camelid endemic to South America. Similar to the Bison in the US, it played an essential role in supporting regional ecological resilience. Guanacos have been reduced by 96% of their range due to the introduction of sheep by foreign settlers, leading to native wildlife being heavily hunted to reduce competition with and predation on livestock. As a result, carnivores and scavengers began to consume the introduced livestock. Other endemic herbivores also suffered and are now at such low densities that they are considered to be ecologicallyextinct, no longer fulfilling their role as food for carnivores and scavengers. Traditional livestock practices have degraded pastures and have overlooked the natural restorative impacts on pastures provided by native wildlife. The purpose of this project is to promote wildlife-friendly livestock practices, involving rural producers, governmental and civil society partners. Specific activities include: evaluating availability of pasture for livestock and wild herbivores, implementation of non-lethal control measures for livestock predators, protection of water sources, creating migratory corridors for Guanacos, conducting wildlife surveys, and production and dissemination of extension tools on livestock practices for local stakeholders.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Conservacin de la vida silvestre de la Patagonia: implementacin de prcticas ganaderas sustentables y mitigacin de conflictos con herbvoros y carnvoros nativos.

description.narrative: The Patagonia region in Argentina once harbored large migratory populations of Guanacos (Lama guanicoe), a camelid endemic to South America. Similar to the Bison in the US, it played an essential role in supporting regional ecological resilience. Guanacos have been reduced by 96% of their range due to the introduction of sheep by foreign settlers, leading to native wildlife being heavily hunted to reduce competition with and predation on livestock. As a result, carnivores and scavengers began to consume the introduced livestock. Other endemic herbivores also suffered and are now at such low densities that they are considered to be ecologicallyextinct, no longer fulfilling their role as food for carnivores and scavengers. Traditional livestock practices have degraded pastures and have overlooked the natural restorative impacts on pastures provided by native wildlife. The purpose of this project is to promote wildlife-friendly livestock practices, involving rural producers, governmental and civil society partners. Specific activities include: evaluating availability of pasture for livestock and wild herbivores, implementation of non-lethal control measures for livestock predators, protection of water sources, creating migratory corridors for Guanacos, conducting wildlife surveys, and production and dissemination of extension tools on livestock practices for local stakeholders.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Promoting sustainable land and natural resource use at Somuncura Plateau

description.narrative: The Somuncura Plateau in Patagonia, Argentina, spans approximately 30,888,173 acres and sustains multiple threatened and endemic species, including the Laguna Raimunda Frog (Atelognathus reverberii), the El Rincon Stream Frog (Pleurodema somuncurense), the Naked Characin (Gymnocharacinus bergii), Andean Condors (Vultur gryphus), Vultures (Cathartes aura, Coragyps atratus), Caracaras (Caracara plancus, Milvago chimango), Greater and Lesser Rheas (Rhea americana, Pterocnemia pennata), Maras (Dolichotis patagonum) and Guanacos (Lama guanicoe). These species are threatened by unsustainable livestock practices, invasive species, and human-wildlife conflict. Areas around natural freshwater sources are trampled, contaminated, and over-grazed by livestock; aquatic vertebrates are decimated by invasive rainbow trout; and farmers illegally hunt and poison native predators. This project will address these threats and promote opportunities for ecotourism as an alternative, sustainable activity. Specific activities include: sustainable management of water sources, specifically protecting them from livestock trampling and overgrazing; controlling destructive invasive species; introducing shepherd dogs to mitigate human-wildlife conflict related to predators and livestock; an educational campaign to reduce or eliminate illegal hunting and the use of poisons against predators; and the promotion of ecotourism as an alternative and sustainable activity. Proposed activities build on past collaboration and participation of local stakeholders and decision-makers.

title.narrative: WILDLIFE FRIENDLY PATAGONIAN FIBER: BUILDING CAPACITY FOR SUSTAINABILITY OF GUANACO USE

description.narrative: To promote certified wildlife friendly practices as a conservation tool to reverse the negative effects of traditional livestock husbandry and generate local socio-economic development from the high market value of these fibers. Project activities include fostering wildlife friendly certification for producers, promoting the sustainable use of wild Guanaco populations through live-shearing events that follow proven safety protocols, and connecting wildlife friendly producers with national and international textile sectors.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF TWO NMB FOCAL SPECIES SO

description.narrative: This project will improve the conservation status of Red Knot and Hudsonian Godwit in southern Patagonia in Argentina. The objectives are to: 1) build and consolidate local support for conservation actions; 2) expand the area and the degree of protection of urban natural reserves; and 3) increase community awareness through innovative methodologies, such as social marketing and reducing barriers to positive behavior change. The project will reduce the most significant threats to key shorebird areas, including dumping of waste and the disturbance of birds by vehicles, pets and recreational activities.

title.narrative: SAVING MAR CHIQUITA WETLANDS

description.narrative: Covering 2.5 million acres, the Mar Chiquita lake and associated wetlands and grasslands are the largest saline wetland system in South America and one of the most biodiverse ecosystems in Argentina. More than 40,000 people live in the area. This project supports the long-term goal of attaining formal protection of the wetland system through the creation of Ansenuza National Park and through the effective management of both the National Park and a Provincial Multiple Use Reserve. The project will consolidate progress toward this long-term process through several objectives: 1) acquiring at least 13,000 acres; 2) finalizing the National Park declaration process; 3) obtaining baseline information about neotropical migratory bird populations; 4) developing management guidelines; 5) setting up governance arrangements for the effective implementation of the national and provincial parks; 6) building awareness and capacity among community members; and 7) strengthening local economies through alternative, sustainable activities.

title.narrative: PROMOTING SUSTAINABLE LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCE USE AT SOMUNCURA PLATEAU II

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support conservation efforts in the Somuncura Plateau, Patagonia, Argentina, by increasing the habitat for endangered species, reducing human wildlife conflict, and promoting ecotourism as a profitable and sustainable activity. The Somuncura Plateau in Patagonia, Argentina, spans approximately 30,888,173 acres and sustains multiple threatened and endemic species, including the Laguna Raimunda Frog (Atelognathus reverberii), the El Rincon Stream Frog (Pleurodema somuncurense), the Naked Characin (Gymnocharacinus bergii), Andean Condors (Vultur gryphus), Vultures (Cathartes aura, Coragyps atratus), Caracaras (Caracara plancus, Milvago chimango), Greater and Lesser Rheas (Rhea americana, Pterocnemia pennata), Maras (Dolichotis patagonum) and Guanacos (Lama guanicoe). These species are threatened by unsustainable livestock practices, invasive species, and human-wildlife conflict. Areas around natural freshwater sources are trampled, contaminated, and over-grazed by livestock; aquatic vertebrates are decimated by invasive rainbow trout; and farmers illegally hunt and poison native predators.

title.narrative: IMPLEMENTING THE ARGENTINE SHOREBIRD CON

description.narrative: The Argentine Shorebird Conservation Plan provides a national framework to guide the efforts of public and private institutions, academia and civil society, and seeks to increase and strengthen the collective capacity for action to conserve shorebirds, at the national, provincial and local levels. This project represents the first part of its implementation and has five main components: 1) Strengthen baseline information on species and habitats at priority sites to inform and measure the effectiveness of management; 2) Develop and implement new mechanisms for recognition and protection of priority sites; 3) Safeguard and manage critical habitats through the implementation of collaborative solutions at the site scale; 4) Build capacity and agreements for good governance in site management and 5) Raise awareness and involve communities in conservation processes. This first phase of the Plan implementation will be piloted in five key shorebird sites: Punta Rasa, Albfera Mar Chiquita, Laguna Llancanelo, Laguna de los Pozuelos and Ansenuza.

title.narrative: REDUCING FOREST DEGRADATION THROUGH SUSTAINABLE GOAT PRODUCTS IN THE DRY CHACO ECOREGION

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT BIODIVERSITY AND DECREASE FOREST DEGRADATION IN THE ARGENTINE CHACO REGION THROUGH A WILDLIFE-FRIENDLY GOAT PRODUCTION SCHEME AND A SOCIAL MARKETING CAMPAIGN. FREE-RANGING GOATS GENERALLY OVERGRAZE WHICH IN TURN CAUSES FOREST DEGRADATION OVER THOUSANDS OF HA IN THE CHACO. FURTHERMORE, PREDATION ON FREE-RANGING GOATS LEADS TO REVENGE KILLING. REDUCING FREE-RANGING GOATS IS KEY TO RESTORE DEGRADED AREAS AND CONSERVE THIS UNIQUE ECOSYSTEM. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE THE CHACO FOREST IN GENERAL, AS WELL AS SPECIES THAT ARE HIGHLY SENSITIVE TO FOREST DEGRADATION AND REVENGE KILLING, LIKE THE GIANT ANTEATER MYRMECOPHAGA TRIDACTYLA , THE PUMA PUMA CONCOLOR , AND THE BLACK-CAPPED WARBLING FINCH MICROSPINGUS MELANOLEUCUS . WE AIM TO CONSERVE THESE SPECIES BY DECREASING OVERGRAZING BY GOATS AND REVENGE KILLING. MAIN SPECIFIC ACTIONS INCLUDE 1 STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT 2 ENCOURAGE ADOPTION OF A WILDLIFE-FRIENDLY GOAT PRODUCTS BY PROVIDING A SUSTAINABLE GOAT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM THROUGH REGENERATIVE LIVESTOCK RAISING THAT REDUCES THE NUMBER OF FREE-RANGING GOATS IN THE FOREST AND EMPOWERS CAMPESINO WOMEN AND 3 A SOCIAL MARKETING CAMPAIGN AIMED AT INCREASING DEMAND FOR WILDLIFE FRIENDLY GOAT PRODUCTS.
